block.p: A leading investment banking firm specializing in advertising and marketing deals is predicting more major transactions to come like the acquisition of Young & Rubicam by the WPP Group.

Ad Media Partners Inc. in New York is distributing copies of its sixth annual survey on Madison Avenue deals. The survey found that industry executives said they expected the volume of deals to be the same as last year or even higher than last year; only 6 percent said they believed there would be fewer deals.
A leading investment banking firm specializing in advertising and marketing deals is predicting more major transactions to come like the acquisition of Young & Rubicam by the WPP Group.

Ad Media Partners Inc. in New York is distributing copies of its sixth annual survey on Madison Avenue deals. The survey found that industry executives said they expected the volume of deals to be the same as last year or even higher than last year; only 6 percent said they believed there would be fewer deals.

The 51 percent of the respondents who said they expected the same amount of activity as 1999, and the 43 percent who said they expected more, gave identical reasons for their opinions: the impact of new technology and the Internet on the advertising and marketing industries as well as the continuation of the trend to consolidate agencies.
